dictionary.definition: to assume that someone is stupid.  I wouldn’t do anything like that! Do you take me for an idiot? _ I don’t take you for a fool. I think you’re very clever.
to assume that someone is stupid.  I wouldn’t do anything like that! Do you take me for an idiot? _ I don’t take you for a fool. I think you’re very clever.

dictionary.phrase: take someone or something into account
dictionary.definition: to remember to consider someone or something.  I hope you’ll take Bill and Bob into account when you plan the party. I’ll try to take into account all the things that are important in a situation like this.

dictionary.phrase: take into account someone or something
dictionary.definition: to remember to consider someone or something.  I hope you’ll take Bill and Bob into account when you plan the party. I’ll try to take into account all the things that are important in a situation like this.

dictionary.phrase: take someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to carry, lead, or guide someone or something out of something or some place. He was becoming quite ill from the smoke, and I had to take him out of the room.  They took out the injured people.
to carry, lead, or guide someone or something out of something or some place. He was becoming quite ill from the smoke, and I had to take him out of the room.  They took out the injured people.
to believe what someone says about something without seeking further information or proof.  It’s true! Take my word for it.  I can’t prove it. You will have to take my word on it.
to believe what someone says about something without seeking further information or proof.  It’s true! Take my word for it.  I can’t prove it. You will have to take my word on it.
to understand something as wrong or insulting.  Would you take it amiss if I told you I thought you look lovely? _ I was afraid you’d take it the wrong way.
to understand something as wrong or insulting.  Would you take it amiss if I told you I thought you look lovely? _ I was afraid you’d take it the wrong way.

to consider something to be an important factor in some decision. We will take your long years of service into account when we make our final decision.  You can be certain that we will take it into consideration.

to consider something to be an important factor in some decision. We will take your long years of service into account when we make our final decision.  You can be certain that we will take it into consideration.
to carry something into a place. Fred took the birthday cake into the dining room.  Liz took in the cake for us.
to carry something into a place. Fred took the birthday cake into the dining room.  Liz took in the cake for us.

dictionary.phrase: take something with a pinch of salt
dictionary.definition: to listen to a story or an explanation with considerable doubt.  You must take anything she says with a grain of salt. She doesn’t always tell the truth. They took my explanation with a pinch of salt. I was sure they didn’t believe me.

dictionary.phrase: take something with a grain of salt
dictionary.definition: to listen to a story or an explanation with considerable doubt.  You must take anything she says with a grain of salt. She doesn’t always tell the truth. They took my explanation with a pinch of salt. I was sure they didn’t believe me.

dictionary.phrase: take the bit in one’s teeth
dictionary.definition: to put oneself in charge; to take charge.  Someone needed to direct the project, so I took the bit in my teeth.  If you want to get something done, you’ve got to take the bit between your teeth and get to work.

dictionary.phrase: take the bit between the teeth
dictionary.definition: to put oneself in charge; to take charge.  Someone needed to direct the project, so I took the bit in my teeth.  If you want to get something done, you’ve got to take the bit between your teeth and get to work.
Sl. to receive or put up with criticism (for something).  The cops have been taking some heat about the Quincy killing.  If you can’t take the heat, stay out of the kitchen.
Sl. to receive or put up with criticism (for something).  The cops have been taking some heat about the Quincy killing.  If you can’t take the heat, stay out of the kitchen.
to remove the lid from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I took the lid off the box and set it aside.  Karen took off the lid.
to remove the lid from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I took the lid off the box and set it aside.  Karen took off the lid.
[for two or more people] to alternate in doing something. Let’s take turns with mowing the lawn.  Do you want to take turns at answering the telephone?
[for two or more people] to alternate in doing something. Let’s take turns with mowing the lawn.  Do you want to take turns at answering the telephone?
[for two or more people] to alternate in doing something. Let’s take turns with mowing the lawn.  Do you want to take turns at answering the telephone?
to fill or occupy space. (Note the variations in the examples.) _The piano is taking up too much room in our living room.  John, you’re not being any help at all. You’re just taking up space.
to fill or occupy space. (Note the variations in the examples.) _The piano is taking up too much room in our living room.  John, you’re not being any help at all. You’re just taking up space.
to fill one’s fuel tank with something.  I need to tank up on premium gas to stop this engine knock.  It’s time to stop and tank up.  We need to tank up with gas.
to fill one’s fuel tank with something.  I need to tank up on premium gas to stop this engine knock.  It’s time to stop and tank up.  We need to tank up with gas.
to move something in with light blows. The mechanic tapped the bracket into place.  The worker tapped in the bracket.
to move something in with light blows. The mechanic tapped the bracket into place.  The worker tapped in the bracket.

a sample of the unpleasantness that one has been giving other people. (*Typically: get ~; have ~; give someone ~.) _ Now you see how it feels to have someone call you names! You are getting a taste of your own medicine! _ John, who is often rude and abrupt with people, was devastated when the teacher treated him rudely. He doesn’t like having a dose of his own medicine.

a sample of the unpleasantness that one has been giving other people. (*Typically: get ~; have ~; give someone ~.) _ Now you see how it feels to have someone call you names! You are getting a taste of your own medicine! _ John, who is often rude and abrupt with people, was devastated when the teacher treated him rudely. He doesn’t like having a dose of his own medicine.

dictionary.phrase: tear someone or something to pieces
dictionary.definition: to rip or shred someone or something into bits.  Careful of that dog. It will tear you to pieces! _ The dog tore the newspaper to pieces.  It tore my shoes to shreds.

dictionary.phrase: tear someone or something to shreds
dictionary.definition: to rip or shred someone or something into bits.  Careful of that dog. It will tear you to pieces! _ The dog tore the newspaper to pieces.  It tore my shoes to shreds.
to remove something from something by ripping or tearing. Tear the coupons out of the magazine and save them.  Please tear out the coupons.
to remove something from something by ripping or tearing. Tear the coupons out of the magazine and save them.  Please tear out the coupons.
to lure something out of something by teasing or tempting.  I managed to tease the cat out of the tree with a bit of fish.  I teased out the cat.
to lure something out of something by teasing or tempting.  I managed to tease the cat out of the tree with a bit of fish.  I teased out the cat.
[for the state of something] to indicate clearly what has happened.  The upturned boat told its own tale. The fisherman had drowned.  The girl’s tear-stained face told its own story.
[for the state of something] to indicate clearly what has happened.  The upturned boat told its own tale. The fisherman had drowned.  The girl’s tear-stained face told its own story.
to distinguish one from another.  I can’t tell Chuck from Roger. They look so much alike.  I can’t tell orange from yellow.
to distinguish one from another.  I can’t tell Chuck from Roger. They look so much alike.  I can’t tell orange from yellow.

an argument or disagreement over a very minor matter.  The entire issue of who was to present the report was just a tempest in a teapot.  The argument at the office turned into a tempest in a teacup. No one really cared about the outcome.

an argument or disagreement over a very minor matter.  The entire issue of who was to present the report was just a tempest in a teapot.  The argument at the office turned into a tempest in a teacup. No one really cared about the outcome.

to threaten or frighten someone into doing something. The salesman is just trying to terrify you into buying a new car by saying the one you have is dangerous.  They tried to terrorize people into staying off the streets.

to threaten or frighten someone into doing something. The salesman is just trying to terrify you into buying a new car by saying the one you have is dangerous.  They tried to terrorize people into staying off the streets.

Oh, I am so thankful! _ John: Well, we finally got here. Sorry we’re so late. Mother: Thank goodness! We were all so worried.  Jane: There was a fire on Maple Street, but no one was hurt. Bill: Thank heavens!

Oh, I am so thankful! _ John: Well, we finally got here. Sorry we’re so late. Mother: Thank goodness! We were all so worried.  Jane: There was a fire on Maple Street, but no one was hurt. Bill: Thank heavens!

a polite expression said to a host or hostess on departure.  Mary: Good-bye, glad you could come. Bill: I had a great time. Thank you for inviting me. John: I had a good time. Thank you for inviting me. Sally: Come back again, John. It was good talking to you.

a polite expression said to a host or hostess on departure.  Mary: Good-bye, glad you could come. Bill: I had a great time. Thank you for inviting me. John: I had a good time. Thank you for inviting me. Sally: Come back again, John. It was good talking to you.

a polite expression said to a host or hostess on departure.  Mary: Good-bye, glad you could come. Bill: I had a great time. Thank you for inviting me. John: I had a good time. Thank you for inviting me. Sally: Come back again, John. It was good talking to you.
a more polite and emphatic way of saying Thank you.  Tom: Welcome. Come in. Bob: Thank you very much. Bill: Here’s the book I promised you. Sue: Thank you so much.
a more polite and emphatic way of saying Thank you.  Tom: Welcome. Come in. Bob: Thank you very much. Bill: Here’s the book I promised you. Sue: Thank you so much.
Thank you for giving me a ride in your car.  John (stopping the car): Here we are. Bob: Thanks for the ride. Bye. John: Later.  As Fred got out of the car, he said, “Thanks for the lift.”
Thank you for giving me a ride in your car.  John (stopping the car): Here we are. Bob: Thanks for the ride. Bye. John: Later.  As Fred got out of the car, he said, “Thanks for the lift.”
Inf. That is all of it.; That is the last of it.  Here’s the last one we have to fix. There, that’s all she wrote. That’s what she wrote. There ain’t no more.

Someone does not need that at all.; That’s the last straw! (Always sarcastic. The someone can be a person’s name or a pronoun.) _ Jane: The dog died and the basement is just starting to f lood. Fred: That’s all we need.  Sally: Bill, the check you wrote to the Internal Revenue Service was returned. There’s no more money in the bank. Bill: That’s all we need.  Bob: On top of having too many bills to pay, now I have car trouble! Mary: That’s just what you need!

That is agreeable as far as I am concerned. (The expressions with by are colloquial.) _ Sue: I’m giving away your old coat. Bob: That’s fine with me.  Sally: Can I take twenty dollars out of your wallet? Fred: That’s okay by me—if you can find it, of course.

Inf. That is the normal way of things.; That is fate.  Mary: All my roses died in the cold weather. Sue: That’s the way it goes. Sally: Someone stole all the candy we left out in the front office. Jane: That’s just how it goes.

Inf. That is the normal way of things.; That is fate.  Mary: All my roses died in the cold weather. Sue: That’s the way it goes. Sally: Someone stole all the candy we left out in the front office. Jane: That’s just how it goes.

That is my child of whom I am proud.; I’m proud of this young person.  After the game, Tom’s dad said, “That’s my boy!” _ That’s my girl! Always a winner!

dictionary.phrase: That’s the way the ball bounces.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You cannot control everything that happens to you.; You should accept the bad things that happen. Bill: I bought a hundred lottery tickets this week, but I still didn’t win! Alan: That’s the way the ball bounces. I was planning to have fun on my vacation, but I’ve been sick the whole time. I guess that’s just the way the cookie crumbles.  That’s tough, but that’s the way the mop f lops.

dictionary.phrase: That’s the way the cookie crumbles.

dictionary.phrase: That’s the way the mop flops.

Sl. That is worthless.  Yuck! That sucks! _ This meat loaf is terrible. It sucks.
Sl. That is worthless.  Yuck! That sucks! _ This meat loaf is terrible. It sucks.

dictionary.phrase: There are two sides to every question.
dictionary.definition: Prov. There are valid reasons for holding opposing opinions.  Jim: I can’t see why anyone would object to building a city park on the corner. John: There are two sides to every question. Maybe the people who own the buildings on the corner don’t want them knocked down. Fred: Only an idiot would want to go hang gliding. It’s too dangerous. Ellen: There are two sides to every question. Maybe some people think it’s enjoyable enough to be worth the risk.

dictionary.phrase: There are two sides to every story.
dictionary.definition: Prov. There are valid reasons for holding opposing opinions.  Jim: I can’t see why anyone would object to building a city park on the corner. John: There are two sides to every question. Maybe the people who own the buildings on the corner don’t want them knocked down. Fred: Only an idiot would want to go hang gliding. It’s too dangerous. Ellen: There are two sides to every question. Maybe some people think it’s enjoyable enough to be worth the risk.

Prov. There is usually some truth behind every rumor.  I’m going to withdraw all my money from that bank. I read an article that the bank was in financial trouble, and where there’s smoke there’s fire.

Prov. There is usually some truth behind every rumor.  I’m going to withdraw all my money from that bank. I read an article that the bank was in financial trouble, and where there’s smoke there’s fire.

dictionary.phrase: There’s no such thing as a free lunch.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Cliché Everything costs something. (Can imply that you should be suspicious of anything that appears to be free.) _Fred: This advertisement says I can get an expensive camera for free! Jane: Don’t be so gullible. There’s no such thing as a free lunch. Mary gave me her sewing machine, but I had to give it $100 worth of repairs before I could even use it. There’s no such thing as a free lunch.

dictionary.phrase: There ain’t no such thing as a free lunch.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Cliché Everything costs something. (Can imply that you should be suspicious of anything that appears to be free.) _Fred: This advertisement says I can get an expensive camera for free! Jane: Don’t be so gullible. There’s no such thing as a free lunch. Mary gave me her sewing machine, but I had to give it $100 worth of repairs before I could even use it. There’s no such thing as a free lunch.
an expression used to comfort someone.  There, there. You’ll feel better after you take a nap.  There, now. Everything will be all right.
an expression used to comfort someone.  There, there. You’ll feel better after you take a nap.  There, now. Everything will be all right.

dictionary.phrase: There will be hell to pay.
dictionary.definition: Inf. There will be a lot of trouble if something is done or if something is not done.  Fred: If you break another window, Andy, there will be hell to pay. Andy: I didn’t do it! I didn’t.  Bill: I’m afraid there’s no time to do this one. I’m going to skip it. Bob: There will be hell to pay if you do.  Bill broke a window, and now there will be the devil to pay.

dictionary.phrase: There will be the devil to pay.
dictionary.definition: Inf. There will be a lot of trouble if something is done or if something is not done.  Fred: If you break another window, Andy, there will be hell to pay. Andy: I didn’t do it! I didn’t.  Bill: I’m afraid there’s no time to do this one. I’m going to skip it. Bob: There will be hell to pay if you do.  Bill broke a window, and now there will be the devil to pay.
exceptionally dim-witted. (*Also: as ~.) _ Dumb? He’s as thick as a short plank, more like.  Oh, I’d not say she was stupid. As thick as two short planks, yes, but stupid? Never!
exceptionally dim-witted. (*Also: as ~.) _ Dumb? He’s as thick as a short plank, more like.  Oh, I’d not say she was stupid. As thick as two short planks, yes, but stupid? Never!

a response to a greeting meaning “My state is not as good as it might be.” (Not necessarily a direct answer.) _ John: How are things going, Fred? Fred: Things could be better. And you? John: About the same. Bob: Hi, Bill! How are you? Bill: I could be better. What’s new with you? Bob: Nothing much.

a response to a greeting meaning “My state is not as good as it might be.” (Not necessarily a direct answer.) _ John: How are things going, Fred? Fred: Things could be better. And you? John: About the same. Bob: Hi, Bill! How are you? Bill: I could be better. What’s new with you? Bob: Nothing much.

a response to a greeting meaning “My state is not as good as it might be.” (Not necessarily a direct answer.) _ John: How are things going, Fred? Fred: Things could be better. And you? John: About the same. Bob: Hi, Bill! How are you? Bill: I could be better. What’s new with you? Bob: Nothing much.

a response to a greeting meaning “My state is not as bad as it might be.” (Not necessarily a direct answer.) _ John: How are you, Fred? Fred: Things could be worse. And you? John: Okay, I guess.  Bob: Hi, Bob! What’s happening? Bob: I could be worse. What’s new with you?

a response to a greeting meaning “My state is not as bad as it might be.” (Not necessarily a direct answer.) _ John: How are you, Fred? Fred: Things could be worse. And you? John: Okay, I guess.  Bob: Hi, Bob! What’s happening? Bob: I could be worse. What’s new with you?

The situation will reach a satisfactory conclusion.; The problem(s) will be resolved.  “Cheer up!” Mary said to a gloomy Fred. “Things will work out all right.” _ Mary: Oh, I’m so miserable! Bill: Don’t worry. Everything will work out for the best.  “Now, now, don’t cry. Things will work out,” consoled Sally, hoping that what she was saying was really true.

dictionary.phrase: think a lot of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to think well of someone or something. The teacher thinks a lot of Mary and her talents. No one really thinks a great deal of the new policies.  I think highly of John.  The manager doesn’t think much of John and says so to everyone.

dictionary.phrase: think a great deal of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to think well of someone or something. The teacher thinks a lot of Mary and her talents. No one really thinks a great deal of the new policies.  I think highly of John.  The manager doesn’t think much of John and says so to everyone.

dictionary.phrase: think highly of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to think well of someone or something. The teacher thinks a lot of Mary and her talents. No one really thinks a great deal of the new policies.  I think highly of John.  The manager doesn’t think much of John and says so to everyone.

dictionary.phrase: think much of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to think well of someone or something. The teacher thinks a lot of Mary and her talents. No one really thinks a great deal of the new policies.  I think highly of John.  The manager doesn’t think much of John and says so to everyone.

dictionary.phrase: think little of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to have a low opinion of someone or something.  Most experts think little of Jane’s theory.  People may think nothing of it now, but in a few years everyone will praise it. The critics thought little of her latest book.

dictionary.phrase: think nothing of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to have a low opinion of someone or something.  Most experts think little of Jane’s theory.  People may think nothing of it now, but in a few years everyone will praise it. The critics thought little of her latest book.

1. You’re welcome.; It was nothing.; I was glad to do it.  Mary: Thank you so much for driving me home. John: Think nothing of it.  Sue: It was very kind of you to bring the kids back all the way out here. Alice: Think nothing of it. I was delighted to do it. 2. You did no harm at all. (A very polite way of reassuring someone that an action has not harmed or hurt the speaker.) _Sue: Oh, sorry. I didn’t mean to bump you! Bob: Think nothing of it. Jane: I hope I didn’t hurt your feelings when I said you were too loud. Bill: Don’t give it a second thought. I was too loud.

dictionary.phrase: think someone hung the moon (and stars)
dictionary.definition: Rur. to think someone is perfect. Joe won’t listen to any complaints about Mary. He thinks she hung the moon and stars.  Jim is awful stuck-up. He thinks he’s God’s own cousin.

dictionary.phrase: think someone is God’s own cousin
dictionary.definition: Rur. to think someone is perfect. Joe won’t listen to any complaints about Mary. He thinks she hung the moon and stars.  Jim is awful stuck-up. He thinks he’s God’s own cousin.

This is not quite what I want.; This does not please me. (Compare this with (It) suits me (fine).) _ Clerk: How do you like this one? Mary: It doesn’t quite suit me.  Bob: This doesn’t quite suit me. Let me see something a little darker. Clerk: How’s this? Bob: Better.

This is not quite what I want.; This does not please me. (Compare this with (It) suits me (fine).) _ Clerk: How do you like this one? Mary: It doesn’t quite suit me.  Bob: This doesn’t quite suit me. Let me see something a little darker. Clerk: How’s this? Bob: Better.

a constant bother or annoyance to someone. (*Typically: be ~; become ~.) _ This problem is a thorn in my side. I wish I had a solution for it.  John was a thorn in my f lesh for years before I finally got rid of him.

Inf. intoxicated and unsteady. (Sheets are the ropes used to manage a ship’s sails. It is assumed that if these ropes were blowing in the wind, the ship would be out of control.) _ He had gotten three sheets to the wind and didn’t pay attention to my warning.  By midnight, he was three sheets.

to please or excite someone very much.  John sent f lowers to Ann and thrilled her to pieces.  Your wonderful comments thrilled me to death.

very excited; to be very pleased.  She was thrilled to death to get the f lowers. I’m just thrilled to pieces to have you visit me.
very excited; to be very pleased.  She was thrilled to death to get the f lowers. I’m just thrilled to pieces to have you visit me.

(From boxing, where this is done by a boxer’s trainer to stop the fight.) to signal that one is going to quit; to quit.  When John could stand no more of Mary’s bad temper, he threw in the towel and left.  Don’t give up now! It’s too soon to throw in the sponge.

(From boxing, where this is done by a boxer’s trainer to stop the fight.) to signal that one is going to quit; to quit.  When John could stand no more of Mary’s bad temper, he threw in the towel and left.  Don’t give up now! It’s too soon to throw in the sponge.

(From boxing, where this is done by a boxer’s trainer to stop the fight.) to signal that one is going to quit; to quit.  When John could stand no more of Mary’s bad temper, he threw in the towel and left.  Don’t give up now! It’s too soon to throw in the sponge.

to give oneself willingly to someone else for romance.  I guess that Mary really likes John. She practically threw herself at him when he came into the room.  Everyone could see by the way Tom flung himself at Jane that he was going to ask her for a date.

to give oneself willingly to someone else for romance.  I guess that Mary really likes John. She practically threw herself at him when he came into the room.  Everyone could see by the way Tom flung himself at Jane that he was going to ask her for a date.

dictionary.phrase: throw oneself at the mercy of some authority
dictionary.definition: to seek mercy from a court of law, especially at one’s sentencing for a crime; to seek help from an official or institution.  He pleaded guilty and threw himself at the mercy of the court. It did no good to throw myself on the mercy of the State Department.  Please don’t! I throw myself upon your mercy!

dictionary.phrase: throw oneself on the mercy of some authority
dictionary.definition: to seek mercy from a court of law, especially at one’s sentencing for a crime; to seek help from an official or institution.  He pleaded guilty and threw himself at the mercy of the court. It did no good to throw myself on the mercy of the State Department.  Please don’t! I throw myself upon your mercy!

dictionary.phrase: throw someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to cast or hurl someone or something into something.  The cops threw Max into jail again.  The warden opened the cell door and threw in the prisoner.  We threw the aluminum cans in the bin.
to cast or hurl someone or something into something.  The cops threw Max into jail again.  The warden opened the cell door and threw in the prisoner.  We threw the aluminum cans in the bin.

dictionary.phrase: throw someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to eject someone or something from something or a place.  The intruder tried to throw Walter out of the window.  He went to the window and threw out Walter.
to eject someone or something from something or a place.  The intruder tried to throw Walter out of the window.  He went to the window and threw out Walter.
to force a person to leave a place or an organization.  John behaved so badly that they threw him out of the party.  I was very loud, but they didn’t throw me out.
to force a person to leave a place or an organization.  John behaved so badly that they threw him out of the party.  I was very loud, but they didn’t throw me out.

to include something extra in a deal. To encourage me to buy a new car, the car dealer threw a free radio into the bargain.  If you purchase three pounds of chocolates, I’ll throw one pound of salted nuts into the bargain. She threw in a free calendar.

to include something extra in a deal. To encourage me to buy a new car, the car dealer threw a free radio into the bargain.  If you purchase three pounds of chocolates, I’ll throw one pound of salted nuts into the bargain. She threw in a free calendar.

to assemble or arrange something in haste.  Don’t just slap something together! Use care and do it right.  You assembled this device very badly. It seems that you just slapped it together.  John went into the kitchen to throw together something for dinner.

to assemble or arrange something in haste.  Don’t just slap something together! Use care and do it right.  You assembled this device very badly. It seems that you just slapped it together.  John went into the kitchen to throw together something for dinner.
Sl. Fig. to chat; to boast. (Use caution with crap.) _ Tom could really throw the bull and sound right as rain. You’re just throwing the crap. Can it!
Sl. Fig. to chat; to boast. (Use caution with crap.) _ Tom could really throw the bull and sound right as rain. You’re just throwing the crap. Can it!

dictionary.phrase: thrust something into someone or something
dictionary.definition: to stab or run something into someone or something.  The knight thrust his lance into the villain.  He thrust in his knife.
to stab or run something into someone or something.  The knight thrust his lance into the villain.  He thrust in his knife.

to get a ride from a passing motorist; to make a sign with one’s thumb that indicates to passing drivers that one is asking for a ride. My car broke down on the highway, and I had to thumb a ride to get back to town.  Sometimes it’s dangerous to hitch a ride with a stranger.

to get a ride from a passing motorist; to make a sign with one’s thumb that indicates to passing drivers that one is asking for a ride. My car broke down on the highway, and I had to thumb a ride to get back to town.  Sometimes it’s dangerous to hitch a ride with a stranger.

to look through a book, magazine, or newspaper, without reading it carefully. I’ve only thumbed through this book, but it looks very interesting.  I leafed through a magazine while waiting to see the doctor.

to look through a book, magazine, or newspaper, without reading it carefully. I’ve only thumbed through this book, but it looks very interesting.  I leafed through a magazine while waiting to see the doctor.
Sl. to get drunk. The boys went out to tie one on. They laid one on, but good.

dictionary.phrase: tie someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to seek to establish a connection between someone or something and something. The police tried to tie Sarah into the crime.  They tried to tie in Liz, too.
to seek to establish a connection between someone or something and something. The police tried to tie Sarah into the crime.  They tried to tie in Liz, too.

dictionary.phrase: tie something onto someone or something
dictionary.definition: to attach something to someone or something by tying or binding.  I tied his house key onto him so he wouldn’t lose it.  I tied on his gloves so he would not lose them.
to attach something to someone or something by tying or binding.  I tied his house key onto him so he wouldn’t lose it.  I tied on his gloves so he would not lose them.
very stingy with money.  The manager is very closefisted with expenditures.  My parents are very tightfisted with money.
very stingy with money.  The manager is very closefisted with expenditures.  My parents are very tightfisted with money.

at the end; a long time from now. (Supposedly from a tale about a child—sitting through an opera—who asks a parent when it will be over. “Not until the fat lady sings” is the answer.) _ Relax. It won’t be over till the fat lady sings. We can leave with everybody else when the fat lady sings.

at the end; a long time from now. (Supposedly from a tale about a child—sitting through an opera—who asks a parent when it will be over. “Not until the fat lady sings” is the answer.) _ Relax. It won’t be over till the fat lady sings. We can leave with everybody else when the fat lady sings.

repeatedly; over and over (again).  You’ve made the same error time after time! Please try to be more careful! _ I’ve told you time and again not to do that.  You keep saying the same thing over and over, time and time again. Stop it!

repeatedly; over and over (again).  You’ve made the same error time after time! Please try to be more careful! _ I’ve told you time and again not to do that.  You keep saying the same thing over and over, time and time again. Stop it!

dictionary.phrase: tip someone off† (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to give someone a valuable piece of news about someone or something.  I tipped the cops off about Max and where he was going to be that night.  I tipped off the mayor about the financial crisis.

dictionary.phrase: tip someone off (on someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to give someone a valuable piece of news about someone or something.  I tipped the cops off about Max and where he was going to be that night.  I tipped off the mayor about the financial crisis.
Cliché with no effect; unsuccessful.  All of my efforts were to no avail.  Everything I did to help was of no avail. Nothing worked.
Cliché with no effect; unsuccessful.  All of my efforts were to no avail.  Everything I did to help was of no avail. Nothing worked.

a phrase introducing a restatement of what someone, usually the speaker, has just said.  Father: You’re still very young, Tom. To put it another way, you don’t have any idea about what you’re getting into. John: Could you go back to your own room now, Tom? I have to study. Put another way, get out of here! Tom: Okay, okay. Don’t get your bowels in an uproar!

to understate something; to say something politely. (Note the variation in the examples.) _ She was angry at almost everyone—to put it mildly. To say she was angry is putting it mildly. To put it mildly, she was enraged.

to understate something; to say something politely. (Note the variation in the examples.) _ She was angry at almost everyone—to put it mildly. To say she was angry is putting it mildly. To put it mildly, she was enraged.

to the very end. (Originally nautical. This originally had nothing to do with bitterness.) _ I’ll stay till the bitter end.  It took me a long time to get through school, but I worked hard at it all the way to the bitter end.

to the very end. (Originally nautical. This originally had nothing to do with bitterness.) _ I’ll stay till the bitter end.  It took me a long time to get through school, but I worked hard at it all the way to the bitter end.

as the opposite of what has been stated; contrary to what has been stated.  The brown horse didn’t beat the black horse. To the contrary, the black one won.  Among spiders, the male is not the larger one. On the contrary, the female is larger.

as the opposite of what has been stated; contrary to what has been stated.  The brown horse didn’t beat the black horse. To the contrary, the black one won.  Among spiders, the male is not the larger one. On the contrary, the female is larger.

to walk away.  Not even noticing what had happened, the old lady got up and toddled away.  Sam toddled away, leaving us behind to explain things to the boss.  Wally toddled off, leaving his dinner untouched.  Don’t just toddle off when I’m talking to you!

to walk away.  Not even noticing what had happened, the old lady got up and toddled away.  Sam toddled away, leaving us behind to explain things to the boss.  Wally toddled off, leaving his dinner untouched.  Don’t just toddle off when I’m talking to you!

to do what one is expected to do; to follow the rules.  You’ll get ahead, Sally. Don’t worry. Just toe the mark, and everything will be okay.  John finally got fired. He just couldn’t learn to toe the line.

to do what one is expected to do; to follow the rules.  You’ll get ahead, Sally. Don’t worry. Just toe the mark, and everything will be okay.  John finally got fired. He just couldn’t learn to toe the line.

dictionary.phrase: Too many cooks spoil the stew.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Cliché Too many people trying to manage something simply spoil it. Let’s decide who is in charge around here. Too many cooks spoil the stew.  Everyone is giving orders, but no one is following them! Too many cooks spoil the broth.

dictionary.phrase: Too many cooks spoil the broth.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Cliché Too many people trying to manage something simply spoil it. Let’s decide who is in charge around here. Too many cooks spoil the stew.  Everyone is giving orders, but no one is following them! Too many cooks spoil the broth.
Sl. the brain; one’s mind and intellect.  A little weak in the upper story, but other than that, a great guy.  He has nothing for a top story.
Sl. the brain; one’s mind and intellect.  A little weak in the upper story, but other than that, a great guy.  He has nothing for a top story.

to fall off the top of something very tall. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _Careful there! You might topple off of that wall.  I didn’t get too close to the edge, because I was afraid of toppling off.  She toppled off the wall.  The vase toppled from its shelf in the quake.

to fall off the top of something very tall. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _Careful there! You might topple off of that wall.  I didn’t get too close to the edge, because I was afraid of toppling off.  She toppled off the wall.  The vase toppled from its shelf in the quake.

dictionary.phrase: torn between someone and someone else
dictionary.definition: uncertain whether to choose one or the other.  I don’t know which to take. I’m torn between Fred and Alice.  I’m torn between red and green.

dictionary.phrase: torn between something and something else
dictionary.definition: uncertain whether to choose one or the other.  I don’t know which to take. I’m torn between Fred and Alice.  I’m torn between red and green.

dictionary.phrase: toss one’s hat into the ring
dictionary.definition: to announce that one is running for an elective office. Jane wanted to run for treasurer, so she tossed her hat into the ring. I won’t throw my hat into the ring until the last minute.

dictionary.phrase: throw one’s hat in the ring
dictionary.definition: to announce that one is running for an elective office. Jane wanted to run for treasurer, so she tossed her hat into the ring. I won’t throw my hat into the ring until the last minute.

dictionary.phrase: toss someone or something off (of) something
dictionary.definition: to hurl someone or something from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The gigantic ape was going to toss the woman off of the Empire State Building.  The ape did not toss off the woman.

to hurl someone or something from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The gigantic ape was going to toss the woman off of the Empire State Building.  The ape did not toss off the woman.

dictionary.phrase: toss someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to discard someone or something; to throw someone or something out of something or some place. The bartender tossed Walter out of the bar. The litterbug tossed out the empty can.
to discard someone or something; to throw someone or something out of something or some place. The bartender tossed Walter out of the bar. The litterbug tossed out the empty can.
to cast or throw something into something.  Frank tossed the wood into the fire.  He tossed in the wood.
to cast or throw something into something.  Frank tossed the wood into the fire.  He tossed in the wood.

to refer to a sensitive matter that will upset someone. (Fig. on the notion of touching an injury and causing pain.) _ I seem to have touched a sore spot. I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to upset you.  When you talk to him, avoid talking about money. It’s best not to touch a sore point if possible.

to refer to a sensitive matter that will upset someone. (Fig. on the notion of touching an injury and causing pain.) _ I seem to have touched a sore spot. I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to upset you.  When you talk to him, avoid talking about money. It’s best not to touch a sore point if possible.

a difficult presentation or performance to follow or improve upon with one’s own performance.  Bill’s speech was excellent. It was a tough act to follow, but my speech was good also.  In spite of the fact that I had a tough act to follow, I did my best.

a difficult presentation or performance to follow or improve upon with one’s own performance.  Bill’s speech was excellent. It was a tough act to follow, but my speech was good also.  In spite of the fact that I had a tough act to follow, I did my best.

1. [of meat] very tough. (*Also: as ~.) _ This meat is tough as an old boot.  Bob couldn’t eat the steak. It was as tough as an old boot. 2. [of someone] very strong willed. (*Also: as ~.) _ When Brian was lost in the mountains, his friends did not fear for him; they knew he was tough as leather. My English teacher was as tough as an old boot. 3. [of someone] not easily moved by feelings such as pity. (*Also: as ~.) _ She doesn’t care. She’s as tough as old shoe leather.  He was born tough as an old boot and has only grown more rigid.

1. [of meat] very tough. (*Also: as ~.) _ This meat is tough as an old boot.  Bob couldn’t eat the steak. It was as tough as an old boot. 2. [of someone] very strong willed. (*Also: as ~.) _ When Brian was lost in the mountains, his friends did not fear for him; they knew he was tough as leather. My English teacher was as tough as an old boot. 3. [of someone] not easily moved by feelings such as pity. (*Also: as ~.) _ She doesn’t care. She’s as tough as old shoe leather.  He was born tough as an old boot and has only grown more rigid.
That is too bad. (Said as a reply to someone relating an unfortunate situation.) _ Tough luck, but that’s the way the cookie crumbles. That’s too bad, tough cookies.
That is too bad. (Said as a reply to someone relating an unfortunate situation.) _ Tough luck, but that’s the way the cookie crumbles. That’s too bad, tough cookies.
a difficult task to carry out; a heavy set of burdens.  It’s a tough row to hoe, but hoe it you will.  This is not an easy task. This is a hard row to hoe.
a difficult task to carry out; a heavy set of burdens.  It’s a tough row to hoe, but hoe it you will.  This is not an easy task. This is a hard row to hoe.

dictionary.phrase: tow someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to pull something, such as a car or a truck, into something, such as a garage. (The someone refers to the property of someone, not the person.) _ They had to tow my car into the garage to be repaired.  They towed in my car.

to pull something, such as a car or a truck, into something, such as a garage. (The someone refers to the property of someone, not the person.) _ They had to tow my car into the garage to be repaired.  They towed in my car.
to bring something, such as mud, into a place on the bottom of one’s shoes or feet.  Please don’t track mud into the office.  Don’t track in any mud!
to bring something, such as mud, into a place on the bottom of one’s shoes or feet.  Please don’t track mud into the office.  Don’t track in any mud!
to return something, such as a car, to a place where cars are sold as partial payment on a new car.  I traded my old car in on a new one.  I traded in my old jalopy for a newer car.
to return something, such as a car, to a place where cars are sold as partial payment on a new car.  I traded my old car in on a new one.  I traded in my old jalopy for a newer car.
to fade away, as with speech, words, singing, etc.  Her voice trailed off as she saw who was waiting at the door.  Ken’s words trailed away as he passed out.
to fade away, as with speech, words, singing, etc.  Her voice trailed off as she saw who was waiting at the door.  Ken’s words trailed away as he passed out.

to have something as a goal; to direct something or oneself toward a goal. (Alludes to someone using the sights of a gun to aim it. Note plural use of sights.) _ You should train your sights on getting a promotion in the next year.  Lisa has her sights trained on a new car.

dictionary.phrase: have one’s sights trained on something
dictionary.definition: to have something as a goal; to direct something or oneself toward a goal. (Alludes to someone using the sights of a gun to aim it. Note plural use of sights.) _ You should train your sights on getting a promotion in the next year.  Lisa has her sights trained on a new car.
to go or arrive carelessly or thoughtlessly.  He traipsed over and invited himself in.  She came traipsing in at about midnight.
to go or arrive carelessly or thoughtlessly.  He traipsed over and invited himself in.  She came traipsing in at about midnight.
to get something from someone by trickery.  You can’t trick me out of my money. I’m not that dumb! _Stay alert so that no one tricks you out of your money.  They tricked the information out of Bob.
to get something from someone by trickery.  You can’t trick me out of my money. I’m not that dumb! _Stay alert so that no one tricks you out of your money.  They tricked the information out of Bob.

dictionary.phrase: trim something off (of) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to cut something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I asked the barber to trim the beard off of Ralph.  The barber trimmed off Ralph’s beard.
to cut something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I asked the barber to trim the beard off of Ralph.  The barber trimmed off Ralph’s beard.
to stumble on someone or something.  The place was filled with sleeping people. I tripped over perfect strangers on my way to the door. I tripped on a brick and fell into the wall.
to stumble on someone or something.  The place was filled with sleeping people. I tripped over perfect strangers on my way to the door. I tripped on a brick and fell into the wall.
Trouble is developing. Trouble’s brewing at the office. I have to get there early tomorrow. There is trouble brewing in the government. The prime minister may resign.

Cliché a phrase that introduces an expression of regret or failure.  Bill: Try as I may, I cannot get this thing put together right. Andy: Did you read the instructions? _ Rachel: Wow! This place is a mess! Mother: Try as I might, I can’t get Andrew to clean up after himself.

an attempt to convince someone of something; an attempt to try to get information out of someone; an attempt to try to train someone to do something. (The expressions with shot and crack are more informal than the main entry phrase. (*Typically: take ~; have ~; give someone ~.) _ Let me have a crack at him. I can make him talk.  Let the new teacher have a try at Billy. She can do marvels with unwilling learners.  Give me a crack at him. I know how to make these bums talk.

to place someone into something carefully; to wrap someone in blankets or something similar.  Father tucked Jimmy into bed an hour later than he should have. Please tuck in Jimmy.

to fold or stuff something into something. Please tuck your shirttail into your pants.  Tuck in your shirttail.  When you make the bed, you have to tuck the sheets in.

1. Sl. to fail.  I sort of felt that the whole thing would go belly up, and I was right.  The computer—on its last legs anyway— turned belly up right in the middle of an important job. 2. Sl. to die. (As a fish does when it dies.) _ The cat was acting strangely for a while before she turned belly up.  Every fish in Greg’s tank went belly up last night.

to show enormous disfavor for something that has happened after one’s death.  If our late father heard you say that, he’d turn over in his grave.  Please don’t change the place around too much when I’m dead. I do not wish to be rolling in my grave all the time.

dictionary.phrase: turn someone or an animal out of something
dictionary.definition: to eject someone or an animal from a place.  She turned her own son out of the house.  You wouldn’t turn a cat out on a night like this, would you? _ She actually turned out her own brother!

dictionary.phrase: turn someone or an animal out†
dictionary.definition: to eject someone or an animal from a place.  She turned her own son out of the house.  You wouldn’t turn a cat out on a night like this, would you? _ She actually turned out her own brother!
